ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: how early modern British thinkers understood the world through literature and philosophy
literature is valuable
I developed skills in philosophical thinking and doctrine.
Understanding of intersection of philosophy and literature, understanding of connections between different branches of philosophy
Seventeenth- to eighteenth-century philosophy of mind, epistemology, political philosophy, and aesthetics and their manifestations in contemporary poetry and novels.
Learned to analyze the relation between lit and philosophy
I learned about philosophy and its intersection with literature, and for a literature geek who has been scared of philosophy for years, I learned so much about how the two actually overlap.
I learned about the convergence and dialogue between literature and philosophy in the 17th and 18th centuries.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It leans far too heavily towards philosophy.
Great discussions and great readings!
Wonderful reading list and caring instructor
This course had interesting and informative reading assignments. The class discussions were lively and productive.
Good syllabus, good instruction, good class format

The course offers a unique opportunity to engage with the intersection between literature and philosophy. The readings build on each other and provide diverse perspectives on the same core issues. I think class discussion was sometimes a little slow, especially in the middle of the semester, but this could be vastly improved in an in-person teaching environment.

Prof. Kramnick does a really good job balancing his syllabus between works of philosophy and works of literature, and my only complaint is that, as a more literature-oriented person, we'd sometimes spend a bit more time on the philosophy than a couple of the poems. More balance would be great, but that's a very small thing.

I thought the course was fantastic! We read great texts and had great discussions. I think having a clear focus for the course (an inter-disciplinary look at the connections between literature and philosophy) really helped keep discussions concrete and focused, an issue that I've encountered in other English course I've taken. I appreciated Professor Kramnick's introductory lectures at the start of each class, and our occasional break-out rooms (though I would have appreciated more variation on the standard seminar-discussion from time to time).

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: No complaints, Zoom was fine.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, fantastic course!
yes
Yes. The material covers a wide breadth and is based on critical thinking.
Yes. A rare and important interdisciplinary course for undergraduates.
Yes  it's an opportunity to engage with philosophy in a more creative/flexible way which very few other Yale courses provide (to my knowledge). You'll also enjoy it if you like Romantic poetry.
Yesa fun way to approach philosophy in a formal setting, and lots of interesting conversations.
A really great and unique class! You'll read great texts and come out of feeling like you've really learned something about both disciplines.
